repository.corpname: Kheel Center for Labor-Management Documentation & Archives

did.unittitle: Long Island Railroad Strike Newspaper Clippings
did.abstract: Newspaper clippings documenting the Long Island Railroad strike in 1994.

defitem.label: Contact Information:
defitem.item: Kheel Center for Labor-Management Documentation and Archives Martin P. Catherwood Library 227 Ives Hall Cornell University Ithaca, NY 14853 (607) 255-3183> kheel_center@cornell.edu http://www.ilr.cornell.edu/library/kheel-center

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: On June 17, 1994, the conductors and maintenance workers of the Long Island Railroad (LIRR) went on strike, after two and a half years without a contract. The strike was led by the United Transportation Union (UTU) after negotiations concerning pay rates and work rules between the UTU and the Metropolitan Tranportation Authority (MTA), the LIRR's parent company, broke down. The strike lasted for two days until New York Governor Mario M. Cuomo and his aides stepped in to impose a contract settlement on the LIRR management, ending the contract dispute.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of newspaper clippings from various New York City newspapers documenting the Long Island Railroad strike in 1994.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to the collections in the Kheel Center is restricted. Please contact a reference archivist for access to these materials.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection must be used in keeping with the Kheel Center Information Sheet and Procedures for Document Use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Long Island Railroad Strike Newspaper Clippings #5963m. Kheel Center for Labor-Management Documentation and Archives, Cornell University Library.

controlaccess.subject: Railroads -- Labor unions -- New York (State)
Strikes and lockouts -- Railroads -- New York (State)

did.unittitle: Long Island Railroad Strike newspaper clippings
Item 1: Belzer, M. (June 19, 1994). "Should LIRR Come Under Anti-Strike Law?" New York Newsday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Article written by Cornell University ILR professor about the history of collective bargaining between the LIRR and its controlling entity, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and the United Transportation Union. Specifically, it focuses on the Railway Labor Act and New York State's Taylor Law, and how these apply to the LIRR. The article is annotated.

did.unittitle: Item 2: Finder, A. (1994, June 21). "Ripples of L.I.R.R. Pact Not Likely to Reach City." New York Times.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Article focuses on outcome of LIRR strike with focus on how the LIRR, because it is a railway subject to regulation under interstate commerce laws, are unlikely to effect the legality of strikes by New York City subway and bus workers

did.unittitle: Item 3: Marks, P. (1994, June 21). "With Jabs at M.T.A. Chief, Cuomo Defends rail-Strike Pact." New York Times.
Item 4: Goodman, L. (1994, June 21). "LIRR deal puts gov, MTA boss on track for collision." New York Post.
Item 5: (1994, June 21). "LIRR strike: worse than nothing." New York Daily News.
Item 6: Dicker, F. "[missing] labor vote in pushing rail act." New York Post.
Item 7: Horvath, A., Smith, A., & Johnson, J. (1994, June 18). "'No Excuse" Cuomo pushes for LIRR pact." Newsday.
Item 8: Rayman, G. (1994, June 18). "Commuters avoid rush-hour horror." Newsday.
Item 9: Clifford, T. & Rein, L. (1994, June 18). "LIRR talks resume." New York Daily News.
Item 10: Lyons, J. (1994, June 18). "Biz derailed by LIRR." New York Daily News.
Item 11: (1994, June 18). "LIRR: Nothing less than hostage taking." New York Daily News.
